conclusion: Understanding the setup and identifying key points
The slider (2kg mass) is ejected at point B with velocity vB
It travels horizontally to point C
At C, it enters a circular arc track with radius R = 0.4m
The arc ends at point D, where the track is tangent to the horizontal ground
Point D is at angle θ = 37° to the vertical (measured from point O, the center of the arc)
The slider then slides along the rough ground (μ = 0.4) from D to landing point E
Analyzing the motion from point C to point D (along the arc)
At point C: Position: at height h = 0.53m
Kinetic energy: ½mv²C (where vC = vB since there's no change in speed from B to C)
Potential energy at point C: mgh = 2kg × 9.8m/s² × 0.53m = 10.388J
Position at point D: at height h' = R(1-sinθ) = 0.4m × (1-0.6) = 0.4m × 0.4 = 0.16m
Potential energy at point D: mgh' = 2kg × 9.8m/s² × 0.16m = 3.136J
From conservation of energy: ½mvC² + mghC = ½mvD² + mghD
Determining the direction of velocity at point D
At point D, the velocity is tangent to the circular arc.
Since the angle θ = 37°, the velocity makes an angle of (90° - 37°) = 53° with the horizontal.
Analyzing the motion from point D to point E (along the ground)
